experimental_sections.heading: Plausibly, the void space observed in the film using X-ray CT is not due to an experimental artifact 269
experimental_sections.text:

15 
 
but represents the action of Fast-PETase. Therefore, it can be concluded that gradual erosion from 270 
the surface is the major mode by which Fast-PETase attacks the PET film; however, erosion inside 271 
the film sometimes occurs at a later stage of the reaction.  272 
Moreover, one side of the film surface became rougher than the other as the reaction 273 
progressed (Figure 4A–4D). Although this indicates a difference in the rate of structural decay of 274 
the two surfaces of the film, the reason for the difference is not clear. However, this phenomenon 275 
can be attributed to the method of preparation of the amorphous PET film. In other words, PET 276 
film preparation could be one of the keys to controlling the enzymatic digestibility, which is 277 
important for developing highly degradable PET materials.  278 
 279 
3.4. SEM analysis 280 
 SEM observation in top-view clearly demonstrated that the initially very flat and smooth 281 
surface of the PET film before degradation (Figure 4A and 4B) became undulated after 282 
degradation by Fast-PETase (Figure 4C and 4D), as previously reported [9, 11]. Observations of 283 
the surface from the side confirmed the presence of depressions that were not convex (Figure 4D).  284 
 285 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
16 
 
Figure 4.  SEM images of PET film before (A and B) after degradation for 26.5 h (C and 286 
D). Scale bars indicate 10 μm except for B where it represents 1 μm. (A and B): PET 287 
before degradation at magnification of ×1,000 (A) and ×10,000 (B). (C and D): Largely 288 
degraded part of the PET film observed at a magnification of ×1,000 in top-view (C) and 289 
side-view from the edge (D).  290 
 291 
The films were further observed at different degradation times to track the structural 292 
changes in the amorphous PET film induced by Fast-PETase (Figure 5). Before degradation, the 293 
surface was flat and smooth, whereas after 4 h of degradation, many depressions having a 294 
diameter of 1 μm were apparent. Given that areas of undegraded surface were found close to these 295 
depressions, the depressions were structures generated by Fast-PETase in the initial phase. The 296 
surface of this depression was not as rough as that of the PET degraded for 12 h, as shown below.  297 
At 12 h of degradation, the depressions formed at 4 h were not observed, and the surface 298 
appeared flat at a lower magnification (Figure 5D). However, hollows with a diameter of 2‒4 μm 299 
appeared, and the surface appeared sandy at a higher magnification due to the granularity of many 300 
smaller pores with a diameter of 10‒100 nm (indicated by the arrowheads in Figure 5E and 5F). 301 
This hollow structure was also found less frequently at 4 h of degradation and is thus considered 302 
a characteristic feature that appears after the initial depressions (Figure 5A–5C) disappear.  303 
After 26.5 h, the surface became highly rough even at a lower magnification due to the 304 
larger diameter (10 μm or more) of the holes (Figure 5G). Closer observation revealed many pores 305 
with diameters of 100 nm or less on the surface of the depressions (Figure 5H and 5I), which were 306 
found specifically in the hollows of the sample degraded for 12 h (Figure 5E and 5F). Thus, the 307 
hollows with sizes of a few micrometers frequently observed after 12 h of degradation might have 308 
enlarged or fused to form larger holes.  309 
After 55.2 h, the crater-like depressions, which were also found in some areas after 26.5 310 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
17 
 
h, were sufficiently enlarged to expose a relatively flat and smooth surface when viewed at lower 311 
magnification (Figure 5J). However, the higher-magnification images clearly show more porous 312 
surfaces with smaller pore sizes (10‒100 nm) and larger numbers of pores than at 26.5 h (Figure 313 
5K and 5L). These porous features were maintained at 64.5 h, whereas the 1 μm pores became 314 
less; consequently, the surface became flatter with pores of 100 nm or less in diameter (Figure 5N 315 
and 5O). In a wider view (Figure 5M), the crater-like depressions with a diameter of ~50 μm 316 
appeared more clearly. In summary, degradation by Fast-PETase induced hierarchical boring on 317 
the order of 10-5 m to 10-8 in the PET film. 318 
 319

18 
 
 320 
 321 
Figure 5. SEM observation of morphological changes of film surface during treatment 322 
with Fast-PETase at three magnifications: ×1,000, ×5,000, and ×20,000. A–C: 4 h; D–F: 323 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a

The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
19 
 
12 h; G –I: 26.5 h; J –L: 55.2 h; M –O: 64.5 h. Asterisks in B and C show a flat and 324 
undegraded surface, and the arrowheads in E and F show pores with diameters of 10‒325 
100 nm.  326 
 327 
It was thus concluded that the turbidity of the PET film after Fast-PETase degradation 328 
was due to the porous structure generated by Fast-PETase and not to crystallization of the 329 
amorphous parts, as discussed in Section 3.1.  330 
 331 
3.5. SAXS analysis 332 
 Although scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is a powerful tool for visualizing the 333 
fine structure of degraded PET, it only provides a local view of the structure. Therefore, it is 334 
necessary to consider whether the SEM observations truly reflect the structure as a whole. SAXS 335 
was used to visualize the mesoscale structure of the degraded PET film in an averaged view. Two 336 
notable observations were made.  337 
Firstly, the scattering intensity around q = 0.022 Å -1, observed before degradation, 338 
decreased quickly (in the first 12 h) after treatment with Fast-PETase (Figure 6A), indicating that 339 
the structure represented by this scattering feature was selectively attacked and removed by Fast-340 
PETase. Furthermore, this signal shifted to lower q, accompanied by a decrease in the intensity 341 
during the early stages of degradation, as shown in the Lorentz-factor-corrected plot (Figure 6A, 342 
inset). Given the equation d = 2π/ q, where d indicates the spatial periodicity, the size of the 343 
structural component represented by this scattering changed from ca. 290 to 320 Å. Although 344 
careful discussion is required for describing the structure represented by this scattering signal, it 345 
may represent a randomly distributed denser region in a less dense region, which has been 346 
proposed as a “nodule” in some previous studies [25, 26].  347 
 The second specific structural change induced by Fast-PETase was observed as an 348 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
20 
 
increase in the scattering at the q-region below 0.02 Å-1 in the SAXS profile, up to the reaction 349 
time of 12 h. Given the synchronicity with the appearance of small pores in the SEM images 350 
(diameter of 10‒100 nm), this may represent the small pores observed in the SEM images after 351 
degradation for 12 h and beyond (Figure 5), where the contrast between the PET substrate and air 352 
becomes more pronounced due to the boring. The scattering in this low q-region increased 353 
continuously after 12 h of degradation, and finally the scattering profile at 68.8 h followed a power 354 
law with an exponent of −3.2 in the observed q-range (Figure 6B, black line), which provides the 355 
surface fractal dimension of 2.8 (= 6 – 3.2), indicating that the pores with diameters of 10 -7‒10-8 356 
m formed a three-dimensionally rough surface rather than a smooth surface. This is also consistent 357 
with the SEM observations, which showed that the nested porous structures with dimensions of 358 
10-7 m or smaller became dominant after 12 h degradation.  359 
 360 
 361 
Figure 6. SAXS profiles of PET film treated with Fast-PETase for different reaction times. 362 
The degradation experiment was independently conducted to obtain the data in A (earlier 363 
stage of the degradation) and B (later stage). Lorentz-factor-corrected plot (q – q2∙I plot) 364 
is also shown in the inset of panel A; arrows indicate the peak maxima for the films 365 
degraded for 0 h and 4 h. The scattering profiles in B were prepared by merging the 366 
WAXD data with SAXS data as described in 2.4.3. The data acquired after 68.8 h of 367 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
21 
 
degradation were fitted (closed circles in panel B) and followed a power-law with an 368 
exponent of −3.2 along the scattering vector q, as shown by black line.  369 
 370 
Notably, this study revealed several structural changes that occurred specifically in the 371 
earlier degradation stage: (i) broadening of the amorphous hallow in WAXD profiles (Figure 2B), 372 
(ii) removal of the smooth surface, visualized by SEM (Figures 4 and 5), and (iii) a decrease in 373 
the SAXS signal around q = 0.022 Å-1 (Figure 6A). Summarizing these observations, the surface 374 
layer of the amorphous PET film might be slightly more crystalline than the core region and 375 
contains the domain (nodule) structure with a size of around 300 Å. This surface layer did not 376 
allow PETase to bore smaller holes (~100 nm) and yielded less porous features, as observed in 377 
the SEM images. Thus, this study supports the idea that the surface and core structures differ for 378 
amorphous PET films. Feasibly, PETase can be used as a probe to assess the polymer structure of 379 
PET in future studies.  380 
 381 
3.6. Comparison with enzymatic degradation of cellulose 382

results_sections.heading: Finally, the results of this study were compared with the structural changes in cellulose 383
results_sections.text:
degraded by cellulase to discuss a biological strategy for degrading solid polymers. In our 384 
previous study [27], the degradation of bacterial cellulose by crude cellulase was analyzed using 385 
SAXS, where an overall decrease in the scattering intensity was observed, without changes in the 386 
scattering features, indicating that the amount of the cellulose simply decreased without 387 
significant structural changes at the scale represented by q = 0.04‒0.2 Å-1. SEM observations in 388 
the same study also demonstrated that the cellulose microfibrils remained generally intact despite 389 
the appearance of large cavities between the fiber bundles in a bacterial cellulose film [27]. 390 
Another study analyzed the full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peaks in the 391 
WAXD profiles, and also showed that the lateral crystallite size of cellulose decreased because of 392 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
22 
 
cellulase degradation [28]. These previous observations of cellulose degradation are in contrast 393 
to the structural decay of the PET film by Fast-PETase observed in this study (Figures 2, 5, and 394 
6). This is plausibly due to the structural differences in PET and cellulose due to differences in 395 
the assembly of the polymer molecules, as explained below.  396 
Native cellulosic material is generally a woven textile of crystalline cellulose 397 
microfibrils with a lateral size of 10-9‒10-8 m, whereas the PET film is a continuous mass in which 398 
many chains are entangled without a well-defined elementary structural unit, such as the 399 
microfibrils in cellulose. It is assumed that each cellulose microfibril is degraded independently 400 
by cellulase, and the structural features appear to be maintained on average. However, structural 401 
degradation of the PET film by Fast-PETase may preferentially occur close to the surface, as 402 
revealed by the specific decrease in the SAXS signal at approximately q = 0.022 Å -1 at the 403 
beginning of degradation, which is not observed for cellulose. Therefore, the polymer structure 404 
governs the enzymatic degradability. In other words, the design of the polymer structure is as 405 
important as enzyme engineering for realizing eco-friendly PET or plastic materials in general.  406 
The relationship between the polymer structure and enzymatic degradation of cellulose 407 
has aided in understanding the structure of cellulose and the function of cellulase. For example, 408 
the unidirectional degradation of native cellulose microfibrils by cellobiohydrolase was used to 409 
demonstrate parallel chain packing in native cellulose microfibrils [29]. In contrast, parallel-chain 410 
packing in native cellulose allowed the processive action of cellobiohydrolases to be clearly 411 
understood [30-32]. Such interrelated research is also required for PET and PETase to deepen our 412 
understanding of the mechanism of decay of the PET structure by PETase. Thus, studying PETase 413 
from the viewpoint of the PET structure will be a highly valuable strategy for studying not only 414 
PETase but also PET, where many issues remain obscure despite the long history of research [16-415 
18].  416 
Given that cellulase is a good example of the efficient degradation of polymer solids, it 417 
.CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International licensemade available under a
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted bioRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. It is 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted March 27, 2025. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.03.24.645130doi: bioRxiv preprint 
23 
 
will be worthwhile to design a PETase protein by referring to cellulase. The fusion of the 418 
carbohydrate-binding module (CBM) to PETase, which is also found in nature [33], has been 419 
shown to enhance the PET-degrading activity [34-37]. In addition to implementing the absorption 420 
function by CBM, the synergistic effect of mixing enzymes with different modes of action, such 421 
as exotype cellulases (cellobiohydrolases) and endoglucanases, is a promising strategy [23]. To 422 
this end, the mode of action of many PETase proteins must be clarified to design a high-423 
performance PETase cocktail. A cellulase-wise strategy is a promising way to develop higher-424 
performance PETases. This approach is set apart from state-of-the-art technologies, such as 425 
protein engineering with bioinformatics. Polymer structure analysis during enzymatic degradation 426 
is important for the sustainable utilization of plastic materials and for the research and 427 
development of biodegradable plastics.  428 
 429 
4. Conclusion 430 
The multiscale structural analysis in this study revealed that Fast-PETase gradually 431 
eroded the PET film from the surface and bored many pores with diameters of 10-5 to 10-8 m. The 432 
domain structure with dimensions of 10-8 m on the surface of the film was preferentially removed 433 
at earlier reaction times. However, the crystallinity of PET did not change after degradation. In 434 
summary, it was demonstrated that Fast-PETase evenly erodes the amorphous PET film from the 435 
surface. This study provides a perspective on the degradation of the solid PET by PETase. This is 436 
valuable information as a reference for comparing the enzymatic efficacy of PETase variants for 437 
PET degradation that are still to be discovered and will help pave the way for a circular economy 438 
of PET materials in the future by conferring full biodegradability to PET, a conventional plastic.  439 
 440
